q: What are the symptoms of atopic eczema?
a: Symptoms of atopic eczema include itchy, dry, cracked, and sore skin. It can appear as small patches of dry skin or widespread inflamed skin all over the body.

q: When should I seek medical advice for atopic eczema?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of atopic eczema. They will be able to diagnose you by examining your skin and asking about your symptoms and medical history.

q: What are the causes of atopic eczema?
a: The exact cause is unknown, but atopic eczema is often found in people with allergies. It can run in families and may be triggered by factors like soaps, detergents, stress, weather, and food allergies.

q: How can atopic eczema be treated?
a: Treatment for atopic eczema focuses on relieving symptoms. This can include self-care techniques, using moisturizing treatments, and using topical corticosteroids during flare-ups. There is currently no cure for atopic eczema.

q: Are there any other types of eczema?
a: Yes, there are other types of eczema, such as discoid eczema, contact dermatitis, varicose eczema, seborrhoeic eczema, and dyshidrotic eczema.

q: Can food allergies trigger atopic eczema?
a: Food allergies can play a part in triggering atopic eczema, especially in young children with severe eczema. Keeping a food diary may help identify if a specific food worsens symptoms.

q: How does atopic eczema affect daily life?
a: Severe eczema can have a significant impact on daily life, both physically and mentally. It can be challenging to cope with the symptoms and there is an increased risk of skin infections.

q: What are the common areas affected by atopic eczema?
a: Atopic eczema can affect any part of the body, but it most often affects the hands, insides of the elbows, backs of the knees, face, and scalp in children.

q: Can atopic eczema improve over time?
a: Yes, atopic eczema can improve significantly or even clear completely as children get older. However, it is usually a long-term (chronic) condition.

q: What are the symptoms of other types of eczema?
a: Other types of eczema can present with different symptoms. For example, discoid eczema appears as circular or oval patches, while contact dermatitis occurs when the skin comes into contact with a particular substance.

q: What are the symptoms of atopic eczema?
a: Symptoms of atopic eczema include itchy, dry, cracked, and sore skin. Some people may have small patches of dry skin, while others may experience widespread inflamed skin all over the body.

q: When should I seek medical advice for atopic eczema?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of atopic eczema. They will be able to diagnose the condition by examining your skin and asking about your symptoms, medical history, and possible triggers.

q: What are the causes of atopic eczema?
a: The exact cause of atopic eczema is unknown, but it is often linked to sensitivity to allergens. It can run in families and be triggered by certain substances, stress, weather, and sometimes food allergies.

q: How is atopic eczema treated?
a: Treatment for atopic eczema focuses on relieving symptoms and managing the condition. This can include self-care techniques, moisturizing treatments, and the use of topical corticosteroids during flare-ups.

q: What are the other types of eczema?
a: Other types of eczema include discoid eczema, contact dermatitis, varicose eczema, seborrhoeic eczema, and dyshidrotic eczema.

q: What is discoid eczema?
a: Discoid eczema is a type of eczema that appears in circular or oval patches on the skin.

q: What is contact dermatitis?
a: Contact dermatitis is a type of eczema that occurs when the body comes into contact with a particular substance.

q: What is varicose eczema?
a: Varicose eczema is a type of eczema that commonly affects the lower legs and is caused by problems with blood flow in the leg veins.

q: What is seborrhoeic eczema?
a: Seborrhoeic eczema is a type of eczema characterized by red, scaly patches on the sides of the nose, eyebrows, ears, and scalp.

q: What is dyshidrotic eczema?
a: Dyshidrotic eczema, also known as pompholyx, is a type of eczema that causes tiny blisters to erupt on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
